sections.title: A plate armor for Elector Christian I. of Saxony
16th century specialized armor
sections.description: This armor, dated 1591, is a decorated example that falls into the category of plate armor. While arms and armor are commonly associated with warfare, they were, as in this case, also used in other contexts, including tournaments, for parades or ceremonial events. The displayed armor was designed for a particular type of tournament, the foot tournament, and protected the front and back of the torso, as well as the arms and the head.

sections.title: Plate armor
sections.description: While body armor in medieval Europe was formed either by a short-sleeved mail shirt (byrnie), made up of interlocking iron rings, or a garment of overlapping scales of iron, bronze, or horn, the plate armor gradually replaced chain mail. Plate armor is a type of personal body armor made from bronze, iron, or steel plates. Depending on the purpose, be it for combat, a foot or an equestrian tournament, corresponding parts of the body were covered.

sections.title: Components
sections.description: A typical 16th century plate armor consisted of a helmet, a collar to protect the throat and neck, a cuirass (or breastplate), arm armor, i.e. upper and lower arm guards, fingered gloves, leg armor and an armored apron (succinctorium). Here the armor does not include legwear.
The helmet covers the entire head, while the visor can be kept open by means of a pin. The ring collar, arranged in three layers, has leather straps from which the shoulder elements are suspended.

Both shoulder elements allow the arms to moove freely. According to the museum description , the right shoulder also allows it to be used as a rider's harness, allowing to attach a hook for a lance. As seen here, the configuration is intended for combat on foot.

sections.title: Goose belly
sections.description: The breastplate, seen here in profile, has the form of a peascod belly, also called a goose belly, a very popular element in men's fashion from the late 16th to the early 17th century.
The so called belly hoops, covering only the front and upper part of the legs, are attached to the breastplate via prominently featuring leather straps.
Fingered gauntles allow the wearer a good range of motion while protecting fingers and knuckles.

sections.title: The work of the plater
sections.description: The so-called house books of the Mendel (cf. Mendel I, around 1425, Mendel II, around 1670-77) and Landauer 'Zwölfbrüderhaus Stiftungen' from the 15th century, in the possession of the Nuremberg City Library, are a valuable source of images of historical craftsmanship in Europe. For instance, “Mendel I, Mendel II and Landauer II” depict the activities of the plater. They show, as in “this example of a plater from 1592 (Amb. 317b.2°, [Fol 53/r])” the working environment within the brotherhood and the tools of the trade.

sections.title: An Augsburg plate armorer
sections.description:
Anton Pfeffenhauser (Peffenhauser, Pepfenhauser) (around 1527 – 1601) was trained by members of the Helmschmied family and became the foremost master plate armorer in Augsburg during the late 16th century. He made richly decorated luxury armor for the princes of his time, including Archduke Ferdinand II, whose tournament armor is preserved at Ambras Castle in Innsbruck, or for Duke Johann Wilhelm of Saxe-Weimar. This
half armor, created around 1570 and attributed to him is now in the art collections of the Veste Coburg. Pfeffenhausers armor mark shows a free-standing tripot, corresponding to his coat of arms. A copper votive panel from 1586 preserved in the Museo Correr (Venice) shows Plattner with three of his sons, as well as his master's mark in the coat of arms.

The armor presented here is made of iron, steel, brass and leather straps. It measures 1,20m in height, 82 cm in width and 32 cm in depth. Pfeffenhauser finished the metal with a decorative technique called bluing. The bluing process entails repeated gentle heating of the sheet metal until the surface turns blue. Together with the ornamentation in gilded etching, Pfeffenhauser demonstrates the finesse of the craftsmanship in his workshop.
He collaborated with the painter-engraver “Jörg Sorg the Younger (around 1525–1603)” and the goldsmith “Jörg Sigman (around 1527–1601)”. Preliminary drawings of Sorg's decorations 1548-63 are documented in the so-called “Stuttgarter Harnisch-Musterbuch”: 1548–1563 (Württemberg State Library, Cod. Milit. 2, 24).

sections.title: Ornamentation
sections.description:
At the beginning of the 16th century armor decoration frequently features Christian saints, biblical figures, and classical figures, set in cartouches and arranged on the top of the breastplate or embedded in more abstract decorum (e.g. in this example “in this example”). The designs on Pfeffenhausers amor are characterized by lines and linear decorum. An early
Field and tournament armor of Johann Wilhelm (1530-1573), attributed to Anton Pfeffenhauser with etched ornaments by Jörg Sorg, with parts of the large and complex garniture being stored in the Historic Museum Dresden and The Metropolitan Museum of Art, displays the more linear pattern.
It was only after 1570 when he turned to a decorum of leaf and flower tendrils, as seen in the present design. In this armor from 1591 larger-than-life tendril ornaments decorate the front and the back piece of the armor, the elbow protectors and the shoulder elements as well as the gauntlets and are continued on the back of the helmet. The design seems to emphasize the overall unity of the armor.

sections.title: Made to measure
sections.description:
This harness was manufactured in 1591 for the
Saxon Elector Christian I by Anton Pfeffenhauser. Commissioned by the Saxon Electress Sophie as a gift for her husband, it was one of a series of six matching pieces of armor with additional components for various sports.
In the configuration shown, it was used for foot tournaments.

The foot tournament was played in pairs or in a group on a fenced-off course. Long spears and blunt swords were used as weapons. The elector, who was enthusiastic about tournaments, had a special arena built for equestrian games in his Dresden residence, which was completed in 1591.

sections.title: More details & findings
sections.description: The description of “Anton Pfeffenhauser's biography” shows that he was extraordinarily productive for half a century. The armor and its decription can be found in the online catalogue.” of Germanisches Nationalmuseum. More info on the decoration techniques can be found at the “Heilbrunn timeline of Art History.”
